App description:
Wander the world openly through the magic of VR.

From the comfort of your living room you can teleport almost anywhere in the world - whether you wish to walk across the London Bridge, stroll the gardens of the Taj Mahal, or witness the enormity of the Great Pyramids of Egypt - unlimited exploration awaits!

Notable features include:
- Speech recognition for searching
- Wikipedia integration for location-based learning
- Historical jumping to witness changes over the years
- Multiple navigation modes and more

Note: This app uses data from Google StreetView but is not an official Google product.

Senorsenorpedro13 days ago
After bugfixes: worth every penny

I like this app very much, when it works. Unfortunately thats very rare. The first location loads flawlessly, but then it goes downhill. The longer I use it the more slower the app gets, after 2-3 mins its basically only loading indicators. The map also gets just plain blue after zooming in a bit.

Right now this app is in a very sad state and I cannot recommend paying for it. I really hope the developers fix the issues quickly, because when it works its a really nice experience.

Edit: after the update it works really nice, only one small bug: occasionally, after using the random button, the big map is bot updated and still shows the previously location, so its not possible to find out where one is at that point. Apart from that, great app would recommend it to everyone

ZanyZarlyMay 21 at 3:56 AM
No Google Earth VR but still worth it!

I'm a huge Google Earth VR fan, it's something that I hope one day will come to the Quest. I had originally dismissed Wander as a prospective purchase because it sounded little more than Google Street View in VR. Which I suppose it is! But don't let that put you off picking this one up.

I found myself in Google Earth VR "oohing and aaahing" at the ability to fly around cities and countries seamlessly. I never really used it as a street view navigator, it seemed like streetview in Google Earth VR was added as an afterthought. Google Earth in hindsight is all pretty and full of "wow's" but didn't really make me feel like I was visiting places in person.

Wander is impressive in its own right, yes -- it's Street View in VR, which doesn't sound terribly impressive but it's surprisingly very enjoyable to revisit old streets, houses and parks that you haven't seen in years. The VR element puts everything into scale, it's easy to imagine being present in the streets that you are virtually walking down.

TLDR: It's not Google Earth but it's a worthy edition to any Quest owners library.

GorillaSaladApr 23 at 1:29 PM
Probably the best "global" VR experience

This is at its core Google StreetView, which itself is a mashup of years of on-street 360 degree images Google has taken as well as 360 VR images others have taken and submitted to Google. The result can be a bit disjointed; you can traverse images along streets in sequential order, but depending upon the quality of the user-submitted VR sites this may or may not be possible. Image quality varies, though it is typically pretty good. A good portion of the imagery is taken by 360 cameras that are mounted atop cars or held above people, so generally you feel like a ten to twelve foot tall alien viewing all of this. None of this can be changed or fixed by the developer here... they're limited to the medium they're utilizing.
That said, I think they've done a very admirable job in navigating what is a very complex and massive dataset. There is a learning curve to the controls, but lifting the controls in front of your face renders them with every button and stick labeled with its function. It's very easy to identify what everything does, and after an hour or so it becomes second nature.
What you ultimately get out of this will be largely based on your own expectations. If you want a fully 3D, go anywhere in the world adventure, this isn't it... you're limited to the scope of StreetView. It will always be a 360 view of two dimensional images. In most densely populated areas, there's enough imagery to allow you a good degree of freedom in where you go. In less densely covered ones, you're a bit more "on the rails" in what you can explore.
I'd agree with other posters that some kind of selection of ambient noises would add the immersion here, but perhaps you're better off with your own soundtrack though a set of headphones. It would be a massive lift to even tag 1% if the StreetView library with a relevant "soundtrack" for each area. I would like the ability to be able to zoom into individual images a bit if possible to pick out a bit more detail.

Getting a black screen? Read on...

I love this app! Yes, it's basically Google street view, but the VR makes it come to life like it never could looking at a flat screen. I get lost in this app until the battery dies, it's that cool. Originally got it for my Oculus Go, and now that I've upgraded to the Quest it showed up in the Oculus store as a free app.

Unfortunately one of the updates from a couple months ago broke the app for me. I don't have trouble connecting with anything else, just this app. I sent a couple emails to the developer, but didn't get any response. Reading through other reviews, it seems that the problem was related in some way to using a dual band router (2.4GHz and 5GHz). I have a different SSID for the two bands, and it worked perfectly before that update. Setting my phone as a 5GHz hotspot and connecting to that worked perfectly.

Anyway, I was able to solve it permanently by setting up a guest account in my router using the 5GHz radio only. So now my Oculus Go and Quest both connect to that guest account and this app is working once again. Hopefully the developer will address this in the future since I've seen that others have the same problem.

mike.k.kohnkeJun 16, 2019 at 7:06 PM
It's Google Street View in 360

I already knew that the source images are still-shots, but since some others didn't , I thought I'd mention it up front. So just to clarify, yes, the images ARE static, and NOT animated.

If you've used Google Street View, then you've already used this app, just in 2D. That's literally what this is - all of the images are from Google Maps. The difference is that you're immersed in the center of the location instead of looking at it from one angle at a time. It's cool to be able to look around just by turning your head instead of dragging with a mouse. You can also just use the joystick on the controller to look around. It has the same features as Google Maps including user-submitted pics from popular locations.

The one drawback is that everything is viewed from about 12 feet in the air. If you've seen a Google Map car, you'll know that the cameras are on a pole on the roof of the vehicle, so it's not shot at street-level. While you don't really notice this on a computer screen, in a VR setting, it seems like you're floating about 12 feet above the ground. You look down and see the tops of people's heads. Instead of feeling like you're walking down the street, you're eye-level with the 2nd floor of the buildings, looking down on the roofs of cars. Of course nothing can be done about this; it's just an unfortunate result of the source material. Pretend you're riding in the top level of a double-decker bus, if that helps.

The only difference between this and uaing Google Street View is 360 immersion (again, from 12 feet off the ground). If that is what you're wanting and not expecting anything more, you'll enjoy this app. If you want live video or interactivity, don't buy this.

A really good side-along app

This app is a lot of fun, and very interesting. It allows you to use Google Street View and other services to go pretty much anywhere. The real benefit for us though has been as a side-along app for our young children, and our older relatives who want to experience vr, but who it would take more patience than we have to teach them how to work the controllers.

We get in one headset and set it up as following the other, and then we take them on a VR tour. They don't have to push any buttons, or work the controller at all. Which is a pretty killer feature to have in VR. We take them to their childhood home, or their old school, etc.

One Feature Request that I will just throw out there, which I think would be absolutely killer. I understand if you can't do it. I just throw it out there.

That request aside, this is a phenomenal app!

psimaticJun 13, 2019 at 8:51 AM
Worth the price & much more! Few issues

I was really on the fence about this at first but so so glad I got Wander. I don't know I made such a fuss over the ten dollar price now that I've spend a good number of hours already diving head first into the app. First off, I love the gaming experience for the Quest and really see my library expanding but I wanted to make my quest headset a versatile Swiss army knife of uses more than just a gaming device. I might pick up Tilt Brush and or Tai Chi for this fact as well. If you are in the same dilemma as I was - not sure if you'd really get any use out of this, here is what I've done so far: explore all my past homes, neighborhoods, past schools, my Alma mater, places of nostalgia, past vacation spots, epic places I've not yet visited, and also even had my wife show me her old hometown when she was a kid, and I was watching the cast alongside using my phone. I have a list on my phone for places I want to check out later when I jump back in Wander. There are a few issues that definitely does not take away the value of the app - 1. Typing keyboard needs a shift button, the caps lock button makes it an extra click to alternate between upper and lower case letters gets tedious fast. 2. The text field could also benefit from being able to edit anywhere in the beginning or middle. It seems of you want to correct a type-o or add a word in the middle, you have to delete and retype. 3. Sometimes when navigating around using a lot of the buttons, I'd all of sudden jump to the middle of the world (zero coordinates, in the ocean, to the nearest 360 image of some couple in a random location that is not geocoded correctly). 4. The app could use a power optimization update, seems to be a bit more drain than I expected- even with the headset plugged in while using the battery percentage dropped from full 100% to 70% after a couple hours of use...and might go even lower with longer usage. The headset also gets kinda hot. 5. The app seems to stream and render Google Street view images much much faster than user submitted 360 images which take like 5 times longer, like up to a minute to see some clarity in rendering the image. Other than those issues - I've been so happy with Wander. The fact that you can bookmark locations, cut/paste and make folders as well, and also jump back to older Google Street view images, are all really good features to help make this a solid app. Just be aware that images and locations might not be 100% correct cause this is all Google Street view and user submitted. Some funny/weird occurrences due to tourists spotting the Google "orb". Even though the experience is not true VR 3D in the same sense as other VR games, the Wander app has so many uses - you'll get way more value than you expected.
